Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A multidisciplinary, field based study of the little-known Kinda baboon (Papio cynocephalus kindae)."

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The physical, behavioral and ecological diversity of baboons (genus Papio) makes them a fruitful source as analogies for understanding early human evolution. This project investigates a widespread but little known species, the kinda baboon (P. kindae), and probes the physiological and genetic bases of its distinctive behaviors and physical features. Besides being unusually small and juvenile in appearance, kinda baboons appear less sexually differentiated than other baboons. Behaving like females of other species, adult male kindas frequently initiate long grooming sessions, while females often give alarm barks, which is normally a male baboon activity. Unexpectedly, kinda baboons hybridize with neighboring chacma baboons (P. ursinus) which are almost twice their size, and are behaviorally more typical. This research project traces the causes of these species differences from the level of observable behavior and anatomy, through the level of development and hormonal control, to the level of the genome. Over 200 kinda, hybrid, and chacma baboons are trapped, sampled, and released unharmed in Kafue National Park, Zambia. Basic biological data such as weight and body measurements are collected along with blood samples. Specialist labs investigate these blood samples for the hormones and other biologically active components that influence growth, sexual differentiation, and behavior, and produce a high-resolution map of the kinda genome. Physiological differences that consistently distinguish kindas can then be tracked to the genetic level, by comparing fast-evolving candidate regions in kindas with homologous regions in other baboon species.

The project is innovative in combining proven, comparatively low-tech field techniques with cutting edge technology in genomics and hormonal physiology. Most immediately, it fills a major gap in our knowledge of a key primate genus. In the long term, it provides insights into behavioral variation and evolution in other species, including humans. In the wider sphere, the project will train graduate students, further scientific collaboration with Zambian Wildlife authorities, and promote the status of baboons in wildlife tourism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do new traits evolve? Beyond general explanations of mutations providing advantages and natural selection acting to increase the frequency of these new traits in a population, this project embedded this question into a field- and laboratory-based investigation of the Kinda baboon. The Kinda are the smallest living baboons, with males and females similar in body size. Males in particular exhibit behavior that is unusual for other baboons: they seek out and initiate grooming with adult females who are not reproductively receptive. How might this suite of unusual traits have evolved? This study tested several hypotheses that could provide insight into this question, including one that the Kinda growth trajectory is distinctive relative to other baboons, both in its pattern and in its physiological underpinnings. In so doing, it approaches an issue of fundamental importance to evolutionary studies (how does novelty evolve?) from a mechanistic perspective, contributing to discussions on this common topic from across a number of different disciplines.

 One of the threads of this hypothesis that we tested – that the hormones that regulate growth would show differences between Kinda baboons and other baboons – was supported. We measured a number of different hormones that are involved in regulating growth. One that we measured, insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I), has six different binding proteins (IGFBPs), which link together with IGF-I and mediate its effects on growth. These binding proteins in turn are regulated by different variables (other hormones, nutrition, health). One of our key findings is that Kinda baboons, unlike other baboons analyzed to date, lack any detectable IGFBP-3. This is important, because in other baboons, IGFBP-3 carries most of IGF-I in circulation. If levels of IGFBP-3 are so low, then IGF-I might clear from the circulation of Kinda baboons more quickly – possibly one explanatory factor for their small size. This result also illustrates how this project has potential for human benefit in biomedicine. Baboons are often used as physiological models in clinical studies, and the contribution of novel information on the hormonal correlates of small body size in a nonhuman primate model should be of interest for clinical researchers.
